summary: This document is an email chain from April 29, 2020, discussing a whistleblower complaint from an employee at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The complaint alleges misconduct by MCC management, including mistreatment of inmates related to a 'lockdown' and nepotism. The Office of the Inspector General (OIG) is sharing this information with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USAO-SDNY) due to potential overlap with the Epstein matter and the 'lockdown matter'.

persons.name: Dan
persons.context: Recipient of an email forwarding a whistleblower complaint; appears to be a prosecutor with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USAO-SDNY) involved in the Epstein matter.

events.title: Whistleblower Complaint Submission
events.description: An employee at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York submits a complaint alleging misconduct by MCC management, including mistreatment of inmates related to a 'lockdown' and incidents of nepotism.

locations: One Battery Park Plaza, 29th FL, New York, NY 10004
keyFacts: A whistleblower complaint was filed by an MCC employee alleging management misconduct, including inmate mistreatment related to a 'lockdown' and nepotism.

The Office of the Inspector General (OIG) shared the complaint with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USAO-SDNY) due to potential relevance to the Epstein matter and a separate 'lockdown matter'.
The email indicates the whistleblower specifically named members of the MCC executive staff, but the names are redacted in the provided text.
The correspondence highlights internal DOJ coordination regarding overlapping investigations, specifically between the OIG and prosecutors handling the Epstein case.
The document is dated April 29, 2020, which is after Jeffrey Epstein's death in August 2019, indicating ongoing related investigations or administrative matters.
